questions.text: Injury at which of the following marked sites causes failure of dorsiflexion?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 3

 

The site marked as '3' in the x-ray given above is the neck of the fibula. Injury at this site causes failure of dorsiflexion (foot drop) due to injury to the common fibular nerve.

 

Neck of Fibula is the narrowed region just distal to the head of the fibula. The common fibular (peroneal) nerve winds around the neck of the fibula. This makes the nerve vulnerable at this site, and any injury or compression can affect nerve function.

 

Site 1 – Lateral epicondyle

 

Site 2 – Head of Fibula

 

Site 3 – Neck of Fibula

 

Site 4 – Tibia

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Site 1. Lateral Epicondyle: It is a prominent bony protrusion on the lateral side of the distal end of the humerus, which is the bone of the upper arm. "Tennis elbow" or lateral epicondylitis is a common condition associated with the lateral epicondyle. It's caused by overuse and inflammation of the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle, leading to pain and tenderness at the site.

 

Site 2 - Head of Fibula: It is the proximal, rounded end of the fibula, the smaller of the two leg bones. It's located just below the lateral aspect of the knee joint.

 

This is the location of the common fibular (peroneal) nerve, which wraps around the neck of the fibula. Injuries or fractures to the head of the fibula may damage this nerve, potentially leading to foot drop.

 

Site 4 - Tibia: It is also known as the shinbone, is the larger, medial, and anterior bone of the leg, located between the knee and the ankle. It is anteromedially placed in the leg and is palpable along its length. The tibia is a common site for fractures, especially the distal part, due to its subcutaneous position. The anterior surface of the tibia, known as the shin, is easily palpable and is often the site of contusions or "shin splints" in athletes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common fibular nerve's course around the neck of the fibula makes this area a hotspot for injuries leading to dorsiflexion failure, underlining the importance of protecting this area from trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primigravida

 

The procedure shown is an External Cephalic Version (ECV), a technique used to turn a breech fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor to facilitate a vaginal delivery. While it is generally more challenging to perform ECV in primigravida (first-time pregnant women) due to a tenser abdominal wall, it is not a contraindication. The procedure can still be performed in primigravida with caution and proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: This is a definite contraindication to ECV because the placenta covers the cervix, preventing safe vaginal delivery. Attempting ECV in such cases could cause placental abruption or severe bleeding, necessitating a cesarean section regardless.

 

Option C. Multiple pregnancy: ECV is contraindicated in multiple pregnancies (twins or more) because manipulating one fetus could adversely affect the position of the other, making the procedure unsafe.

 

Option D. Ruptured membranes: When membranes are ruptured, there is a loss of amniotic fluid (liquor), which is necessary for the maneuverability of the fetus during ECV. Without sufficient amniotic fluid, the procedure is difficult, risky, and not feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV, though it may be technically more challenging compared to multiparous women. Key contraindications to ECV include placenta previa, multiple pregnancy, and ruptured membranes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a trinucleotide repeat disorder? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frontotemporal Dementia

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders are a group of genetic conditions caused by the repetition of a specific set of three nucleotides within certain genes. These repeats can expand during DNA replication, leading to various diseases depending on the gene affected.

 

Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) is generally not associated with trinucleotide repeat expansions. While some familial cases of FTD may be linked to mutations, such as hexanucleotide repeat expansions (six nucleotide repeats) in certain genes, it is not considered a trinucleotide repeat disorder like the other options provided.

 

Note –

 

Hexanucleotide repeat disorders:

 

  • One subtype of familial FTD (Frontotemporal Dementia) is being associated with hexanucleotide repeat expansions (c8 or c9 repeats)
  • Pick's disease (a variant of Frontotemporal Dementia), characterized by specific pathological findings such as Pick cells and sharp, knife-edge gyri.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) can be linked to hexanucleotide repeat expansions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fragile X syndrome: This is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene.

 

Option B. Huntington Chorea: Also known as Huntington's disease, it is a trinucleotide repeat disorder caused by CAG repeats in the HTT gene. This primarily affects the caudate nucleus of the brain. It is associated with decreased levels of neurotransmitters like acetylcholine and GABA.

 

Option D. Myotonic dystrophy: This condition is due to a CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the DMPK gene. Features include the development of Christmas tree cataracts, gonadal atrophy, and early onset alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontotemporal Dementia is not classified as a trinucleotide repeat disorder, distinguishing it from conditions like Fragile X syndrome, Huntington's disease, and Myotonic dystrophy, which are directly caused by trinucleotide repeat expansions.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation, there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb, and the anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

The Rule of Nines, also known as Wallace's rule, is used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults. This method divides the body into sections, each accounting for approximately 9% (or multiples thereof) of the TBSA.

 

  • Left upper limb: Each upper limb is considered to account for 9% of the TBSA.
  • Right upper limb: Similarly, the right upper limb accounts for another 9%.
  • Anterior aspect of chest and abdomen: The anterior trunk, which includes the chest and abdomen, is considered to be 18% of the TBSA.

 

To calculate the total percentage of burns:

 

  • Left upper limb: 9%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Anterior chest and abdomen: 18%

 

Adding these together: 9%+9%+18%=36%

 

Thus, the patient has burns covering 36% of their body surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total body surface area (TBSA) involved is usually worked out by the Wallace Rule of Nines wherein each upper limb is 9% of TBSA, 9% each for the front and back of lower limb, 9% for the front and back of chest, 9% for the front and back of abdomen, the head and neck 9% and 1% for the perineum.

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers

 

Explanation  

 

The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

 

 

Pressure on a nerve due to sleeping with arms under the head leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. B fibers, which are generally involved in autonomic functions, are not the primary concern in this scenario involving motor and sensory disturbances.

 

Option C. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. It's the opposite; A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers, making them more likely to be compromised under mechanical compression.

 

Option D. Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves: Incorrect. The loss of function is not due to sleep per se but due to mechanical pressure affecting nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situations where pressure is applied to nerves, such as sleeping with an arm in a compromising position, the larger, myelinated A fibers (including motor fibers) are more susceptible to disruption compared to the smaller, unmyelinated C fibers. This leads to a loss of motor function and normal touch sensation, while pain sensation remains relatively intact due to the resilience of C fibers to mechanical pressure.

 

Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres –

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with fever, confusion, and altered mental status. On examination, he has jaundice, reduced urine output, low BP, and a feeble pulse. Lab studies reveal severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Peripheral smear revealed P. falciparum. What is the best treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV artesunate

 

The patient presents with severe falciparum malaria, indicated by symptoms such as fever, confusion, jaundice, reduced urine output, low blood pressure, and laboratory findings including severe anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. Plasmodium falciparum is confirmed on a peripheral smear. Severe falciparum malaria is a medical emergency that requires prompt and effective treatment.

 

Key treatment guidelines: IV artesunate is the first-line treatment for severe malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum in non-pregnant adults. It acts rapidly and is effective in reducing parasitemia and improving clinical outcomes.

 

Once the patient's condition stabilizes and improves, the therapy is typically completed with an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

 

If IV artesunate is unavailable, then the alternative treatment is IV Quinine. After this, once the patient shows improvement, the treatment should be followed up with oral quinine combined with either doxycycline or clindamycin to complete the therapy. This approach ensures a comprehensive treatment regimen for severe malaria, with IV artesunate being the most recommended initial treatment due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chloroquine: This drug is not effective against Plasmodium falciparum due to widespread resistance.

 

Option B. Artemesinin combination therapy (ACT): While ACT is used to complete the treatment after initial stabilization with IV artesunate, it is not the first-line treatment in severe cases.

 

Option D. Primaquine: This drug is used to eliminate the hypnozoite stages of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale and is not the primary treatment for severe falciparum malaria. Although a single dose of primaquine is sometimes given to reduce transmission, it is not the mainstay of therapy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe falciparum malaria, the first-line treatment is IV artesunate, followed by artemisinin combination therapy (ACT) once the patient stabilizes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A person presented with neurological manifestations mimicking UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) palsy and sensory neuropathy. The patient was pale and investigations revealed anemia. The probable micronutrient deficiency is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

The neurological manifestations mimicking Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) palsy and sensory neuropathy, along with the presence of anemia, suggest a possible vitamin B12 deficiency. It can cause a type of anemia known as megaloblastic anemia, which can present with pale skin. Moreover, B12 deficiency can also lead to neurological symptoms such as UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Folate deficiency can lead to anemia, but it is not typically associated with neurological manifestations resembling UMN palsy and sensory neuropathy.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Niacin deficiency can cause pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While it involves neurological symptoms, it doesn't typically mimic UMN palsy.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine deficiency can cause beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. However, it is not typically associated with symptoms mimicking UMN palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, including UMN-like signs and sensory neuropathy, due to its essential role in nerve function. This deficiency can result from dietary inadequacy or malabsorption, leading to anemia and neurological complications. It's crucial to recognize the clinical presentation of vitamin B12 deficiency to provide appropriate treatment and prevent long-term neurological damage.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came with complaints of orange hue over the body with hyperkeratotic perifollicular erythematous papules associated with scaling, which started near the face and slowly progressed to involve the entire body. Islands of sparing noted over the body. Palmoplantar keratoderma noted. Histology shows alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) is a rare skin disorder characterized by orange-red plaques, hyperkeratotic follicular papules, and scaling that typically starts on the face and progresses caudally (cephalocaudal spread) to involve the entire body.

 

A hallmark feature is the presence of “islands of sparing,” where patches of normal skin are surrounded by erythematous areas. The thickening of the skin over the palms and soles, known as palmoplantar keratoderma, is another distinguishing feature of PRP.

Histologically, PRP shows a distinctive pattern known as the "checkerboard" pattern, characterized by alternating areas of orthokeratosis (normal keratinization) and parakeratosis (abnormal keratinization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that typically presents as patchy erythematous lesions, often resembling eczema or psoriasis, but it does not exhibit the cephalocaudal spread or islands of sparing characteristic of PRP. The histological findings also differ, with atypical lymphocytes being a hallmark of mycosis fungoides rather than the checkerboard pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option B. Follicular psoriasis: Psoriasis, including its follicular variant, usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered by silvery scales. While it may involve the palms and soles, the orange hue, islands of sparing, and cephalocaudal spread are not typical of psoriasis. Histologically, psoriasis shows uniform parakeratosis and elongation of the rete ridges rather than the alternating pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis: Also known as Darier's disease, keratosis follicularis presents with greasy, warty papules, often in seborrheic areas. It lacks the distinctive orange hue, islands of sparing, and palmoplantar keratoderma seen in PRP. Histologically, Darier’s disease shows suprabasal acantholysis and dyskeratosis rather than the orthokeratosis and parakeratosis found in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by an orange-red hue with cephalocaudal spread, islands of sparing, palmoplantar keratoderma, and a histological "checkerboard" pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis

choices.text: Transcervical resection of septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with a complaint of recurrent abortions. Upon investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • The procedure involves the resection of the septum under hysteroscopic guidance. Hence, it doesn't scar the uterus and avoids the necessity of Cesarean sections for future pregnancies improving the obstetric outcomes.

 

 

Other Options

 

Metroplasty is a type of unification procedures in mullerian anomalies

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty and Option C. Tompkins metroplasty are for septate uterus but are not preferred now. As now the treatment of choice is hysteroscopic resection of the septa.

 

Option B. Strassman metroplasty: Strassman metroplasty is for bicornuate uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum is the best corrective procedure for a septate uterus to improve obstetric outcomes, as it does not scar the uterus and allows for future vaginal deliveries.

 

Ref: Page no 659, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with blurred vision, dry mouth, and progressive muscle weakness after consuming improperly canned food. The symptoms are attributed to a neurotoxin. What is the mechanism of action of Clostridium botulinum toxin? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction


Clostridium botulinum produces a potent neurotoxin that specifically blocks the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This blockage prevents muscle contraction, resulting in flaccid paralysis. The classic symptoms include blurred vision, dry mouth, and descending muscle weakness due to the toxin's effect on cholinergic synapses.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Inhibits acetylcholine receptors: The toxin does not inhibit receptors but blocks neurotransmitter release. 

 

Option B. Inhibits GABA release: Botulinum toxin specifically affects acetylcholine, not GABA.

 

Option D. Increases EF-2 activity: This is not the mechanism of botulinum toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A paint factory worker working since 20 years complains of joint pain, insomnia, fatigue, constipation, headache. He is found to have anemia. Enzyme affected is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ferrochelatase

 

This enzyme is crucial in the final step of heme synthesis, where it inserts iron into protoporphyrin to form heme. In lead poisoning, ferrochelatase is inhibited, leading to decreased heme production, increased ALA production, and symptoms such as anemia, fatigue, and other neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase: This enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase: Similar to Uroporphyrinogen III synthase, this enzyme is involved in heme synthesis. Lead poisoning can disrupt heme synthesis, but Uroporphyrinogen I Synthase is not the primary enzyme affected.

 

Option C. ALA synthase (Aminolevulinic acid synthase): It is a key enzyme in the heme synthesis pathway. Lead poisoning increase activity of ALA synthase. In lead poisoning, product inhibition by heme is  reduced leading to the accumulation of ALA and its precursor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The reference of paint factory worker indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning. Lead affects two enzymes of Heme synthesis pathway:

 

  1. PBG synthase (another name ALA dehydratase)
  2. Ferrochelatase (last enzyme of heme synthesis and adds Fe to its substrate)

 

The defect in any of these enzymes will lead to decrease in haem synthesis resulting in anemia. So, the answer in this case is Ferrochelatase.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 306-307

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A child was born with membranes around the body and had ectropion and eclabium. He is brought to the OPD with lesions covering his face, trunk, and extremities. Which of the following is an unlikely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • The clinical image depicts a newborn covered in a shiny membrane that resembles parchment, suggesting a disorder on the autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis spectrum (Lamellar ichthyosis, Bathing suit ichthyosis, Harlequin ichthyosis)
  • Icthyosis vulgaris is an autosomal dominant condition caused by mutation in the Filaggrin gene (FLG).
  • Ichthyosis vulgaris is unlikely because it does not manifest at birth.

 

Fig: Autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis, Shedding of collodion membranes after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamellar ichthyosis

  • Description: Infants with lamellar ichthyosis are often born with a collodion membrane, which sheds after a few weeks. The skin then becomes darkly pigmented with large, plate-like scales. Ectropion and eclabium can also be present.

 

Option C. Bathing suit ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a rare type of ichthyosis where the scaling is restricted to the trunk, sparing the extremities and face. It's called "bathing suit" due to the distribution pattern resembling the area covered by a bathing suit.

 

Option D. Harlequin ichthyosis

  • Description: This is a severe form of ichthyosis, where infants are born with very thick skin that forms large, diamond-shaped plates separated by deep fissures as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Features like ectropion, eclabium, and respiratory difficulties are common.

 

Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) includes the following:

 

  • Lamellar ichthyosis (LI)
  • Bathing suit ichthyosis (BSI)
  • Harlequin ichthyosis (HI)
  • Congenital Ichthyosiform erythroderma (CIE)
  • Self-limiting congenital ichthyisis (SLCI)
  • Collodion baby

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an unlikely diagnosis in a new-born presenting with a collodion membrane, ectropion, eclabium, and extensive skin lesions, given that ichthyosis vulgaris is typically a milder form and less likely to present with such severe symptoms at birth.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 65 Page no 65.4, 65.6-65.10

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8161842/

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive weakness that started in his lower limbs and is now ascending to involve his upper limbs. Examination reveals absent reflexes in the affected limbs and no significant sensory deficits. He had an upper respiratory tract infection two weeks ago. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

 

Explanation:

 

The diagnosis of GBS is supported by the classic triad of symptoms known as the "three A's":

 

  • Acute onset
  • Ascending paralysis (starting in the lower limbs and progressing upwards)
  • Areflexia (absent reflexes)

 

Additional supporting features include:

 

  • Recent upper respiratory tract infection (often Mycoplasma pneumoniae)
  • Symmetrical weakness
  • Relative preservation of sensory function
  • Post-infectious immune-mediated process

 

(If the patient had a history of diarrhea, the most likely pathogen would be Campylobacter jejuni.)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse myelitis: Incorrect

 

  • Usually has bladder/bowel involvement
  • Reflexes may be increased below the lesion, not absent

 

Option C. Myasthenia gravis: Incorrect

 

  • Causes descending weakness, often affecting ocular and bulbar muscles first
  • Normal reflexes and fluctuating weakness with fatigue

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis: Incorrect

 

  • Presents with upper motor neuron signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski sign)
  • Often associated with optic neuritis and sensory symptoms

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) should be suspected in a patient with acute, ascending areflexic paralysis, particularly following a recent infection.

questions.text: Full form of JSSK is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram


JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was launched in 2005 under the National Rural Health Mission. The older name of JSY was National Maternity Benefit Scheme.

 

Initially, JSY focused only on maternal health, emphasizing the safety and wellbeing of the mother (Janani). However, recognizing the interconnected nature of maternal and newborn health, the program was expanded to include newborn care (Shishu), leading to the creation of JSSK on June 1, 2011 under NRHM. JSSK aims to provide free and cashless services to pregnant women and sick newborns, including transport, medicines, and diet, focusing on enhancing the overall health of both mother and child (upto 1 year of age).

 

Educational Objective:
 

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram, focusing on the protection and care of both the mother and infant by providing comprehensive healthcare services

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume
Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected
Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presented with right-sided rib pain and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray showed a significant right-sided pneumothorax with cardio-mediastinal shift to the left. Which of the following changes will be seen? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume

 

In a pneumothorax, air enters the pleural space, leading to a loss of negative pressure that normally keeps the lung inflated. This causes the affected lung to collapse, significantly decreasing its volume. Concurrently, the thoracic cavity compensates by expanding due to the increase in pressure within the pleural space. This expansion is often accompanied by a mediastinal shift towards the unaffected side, in this case, the left side, as seen in the X-ray. The increase in thoracic volume occurs as the chest wall expands outward due to the absence of opposing forces from the collapsed lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased lung volume, Increased thoracic volume: This option is incorrect because in pneumothorax, the lung volume decreases due to collapse, not increases.

 

Option C. Decreased lung volume, thoracic volume remains unaffected: This is incorrect because, although lung volume decreases, the thoracic volume typically increases as the pleural cavity expands.

 

Option D. Lung volume remains unaffected, Decreased thoracic volume: This is incorrect because pneumothorax leads to a decrease in lung volume and an increase in thoracic volume, not a decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pneumothorax, the affected lung collapses leading to decreased lung volume, while the thoracic volume increases due to the loss of negative pleural pressure and the expansion of the thoracic cavity.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I
Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

questions.text: Following ovulation, the oocyte remains halted in which meiotic phase until fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

 

After ovulation, the oocyte that is released is the secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis. This arrest continues until fertilization occurs. During fertilization, the entry of sperm triggers the completion of meiosis II, leading to the formation of a mature ovum and the release of the second polar body.

 

This arrest in metaphase II is a crucial step in the reproductive cycle, ensuring that the oocyte is ready to complete meiosis only if fertilization occurs, which prevents the wasteful completion of meiosis without fertilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I: This phase describes the primary oocyte that is arrested in prophase I during fetal development and remains in this state until puberty. It is not involved in the post-ovulation phase.

 

Option B. Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II: This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte does not complete prophase II. It arrests in metaphase II after ovulation and only completes meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

 

Option C. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not arrest in prophase II. It arrests in prophase I, and after puberty, it resumes meiosis to form a secondary oocyte.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II at the time of ovulation and remains in this stage until fertilization occurs, highlighting a critical regulatory checkpoint in the female reproductive cycle.

choices.text: Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is started at 14 weeks and continued for 6 weeks after delivery
Iron prophylaxis starts in the 1st trimester and continues till 6 weeks postpartum
Iron prophylaxis is given 6 months antepartum and 3 months postpartum

questions.text: As per Anemia Mukt Bharat, which is the correct statement regarding iron prophylaxis in pregnant women? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron prophylaxis is given for 6 months antepartum and 6 months postpartum

 

Explanation:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative outlines that iron prophylaxis for pregnant women should start from the 14th week of pregnancy and continue throughout the pregnancy (approximately 6 months) and for 6 months postpartum. The recommended dosage is one red-colored, sugar-coated tablet containing 60 mg of elemental iron and 0.5 mg of folic acid daily. This regimen helps in preventing iron deficiency anemia and folate deficiency anemia during and after pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron prophylaxis for pregnant women under the Anemia Mukt Bharat initiative is given from 14 weeks of pregnancy and continues for 6 months postpartum.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has paronychia on their index finger and is also showing a reddish streak on their forearm, as depicted in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxiclav

 

  • The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis, which is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic like Amoxiclav is appropriate for covering both the pathogens commonly responsible for the initial localized infection and the secondary systemic spread.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

It is infection of the nail fold which is characterized by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.

Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus
 

Diagnosis - Clinical

 

Management - Systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.

 

Treatment of Acute paronychia -

 

  • Abscesses - Incised and drained (Abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate).
     
  • Antibiotics - Semisynthetic penicillin/cephalosporin with excellent anti-staphylococcal orally.

 

Complications - Osteitis and amputation.

 

Lymphangitis: represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics with group A beta haemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent.

 

Clinical features: Lymphangitis manifests as red painful subcutaneous streaks & painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity & broad spectrum antibiotics.

 

Chronic paronychia:

 

  • Most common causative organism - Candida albicans.
  • Candidal paronychia is most common in individuals who have their hands in water for a great deal of time.
  • Given recent evidence that Candida colonization may play a secondary role in chronic paronychia, with the primary insult being skin barrier breakdown resulting from wet work and possible contact dermatitis, a role for topical corticosteroids has been demonstrated.
  • Treatment - Topical antifungals & Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Primarily effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa. While useful in skin and soft tissue infections involving anaerobes, it is not the first-line treatment for paronychia or lymphangitis which typically involve aerobic gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Amikacin: A powerful aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for severe, hospital-acquired infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria. It is not typically used for initial treatment of common skin infections due to its potential for causing significant side effects, including nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity, it is generally not the first choice for skin infections and is less effective against gram-positive organisms commonly causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Combination antibiotic Amoxiclav is indicated for the treatment of paronychia complicated by lymphangitis due to its broad-spectrum activity against both Gram-positive and resistant bacteria.

choices.text: To evaluate the risk of surgery
To evaluate the pros and cons of surgery
To evaluate the fitness of the patient

questions.text: Which of the following is the use of Mallampati classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endotracheal intubation

 

The Mallampati classification is a widely used clinical tool for predicting the ease of endotracheal intubation. This classification assesses the visibility of the structures at the back of the oropharynx. The patient is asked to open their mouth and protrude their tongue, and the visibility of the tonsillar pillars, uvula, and soft palate is observed.

 

  • Mallampati classes:
    • Class I: Full visibility of the tonsils, uvula, and soft palate.
    • Class II: Visibility of the uvula and soft palate.
    • Class III: Only the base of the uvula is visible.
    • Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

 

The higher the Mallampati score, the more difficult it may be to intubate the patient. Therefore, this classification is specifically used for evaluating the potential difficulty of airway management, particularly during endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. To evaluate the risk of surgery: The evaluation of surgical risk is typically done using the ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification, not the Mallampati classification.

 

Option C. To evaluate the pros and cons of surgery: This is a broad evaluation that involves multiple factors, including patient history and overall health, not just the airway assessment. The Mallampati classification is not relevant here.

 

Option D. To evaluate the fitness of the patient: General fitness or readiness for surgery involves various physiological and clinical assessments, but Mallampati classification is solely concerned with airway assessment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is used to assess the difficulty of airway assessment, particularly for endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: A child presents with thinning of hair and scaling of the scalp. On taking further history, it is found that she consumes raw eggs in her diet regularly. The given manifestations are due to the deficiency of which of the following vitamins?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Biotin

 

Biotin (Vitamin B7): The given clinical vignette of scaling of scalp and alopecia as well as the history of raw egg consumption suggests biotin deficiency.

 

Raw egg white contains avidin, which tightly binds to biotin and renders it unabsorbable from the intestine. Hence, there can be a biotin deficiency state. Biotin deficiency is known to cause hair thinning and scalp scaling, among other symptoms related to the skin and hair. Biotin is essential for healthy skin, hair, and nails.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition known as pellagra, which primarily presents with symptoms such as dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Thinning hair and scaling of the scalp are not typical features of niacin deficiency.

 

Option B. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine deficiency can result in various neurological symptoms and skin changes, but it doesn't typically manifest as thinning hair and scaling of the scalp.

 

Option D. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, but it does not typically present with hair and scalp issues like thinning and scaling.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The scope of Project MONICA includes: [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cardiovascular diseases 

 

Project MONICA is related to cardiovascular diseases.

 

The WHO MONICA (MONItoring trends and determinants in CArdiovascular disease) Project was designed to measure trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease mortality and coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease morbidity, and to assess the extent to which these trends are related to changes in known risk factors in different populations in 27 countries (10 years’ period)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scope of Project MONICA is focused on cardiovascular diseases, specifically monitoring trends in coronary heart disease and cerebrovascular disease and examining the impact of various risk factors on these conditions.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of asthma and sinusitis. On looking into his medical records, you notice this has been attributed to Samter's triad. Which drug should be avoided in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

In a patient with Samter's triad, aspirin should be avoided as he will have aspirin intolerance.

 

Samter's triad is also known as aspirin-induced asthma or aspirin-sensitive asthma. It consists of:

 

  • Nasal polyposis
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance

 

Aspirin and COX – 1 inhibitors can exacerbate asthma hence they should be avoided. Rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, facial flushing, and periorbital edema are also seen. Aspirin-induced hypersensitivity reactions also may occur.

 

The provocative challenge test with aspirin or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is the only diagnostic method.

 

Aspirin desensitization is an important therapeutic option in patients with ST, especially in those patients suffering from recurrent NPs, anosmia, and overdependence on systemic corticosteroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cotrimoxazole and Option B. Co-amoxiclav: These are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections, including sinusitis, and do not affect COX-1 activity.

 

Option D. Chloramphenicol: An antibiotic that is generally used for serious infections where other antibiotics are not suitable. It does not interact with the COX-1 pathway.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients diagnosed with Samter's triad, it is crucial to avoid aspirin and other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1, as these can trigger severe respiratory and nasal symptoms. Effective management involves identifying safe medications for pain and inflammation and regularly monitoring the respiratory and nasal health of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 193, 194

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

 

The child's presentation of recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea (bulky, greasy stools) is indicative of cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to severe respiratory infections and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

In CF, thick mucus secretions can lead to blockages in various parts of the body. One of the common gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), where thickened stool causes obstruction in the distal part of the small intestine. This condition is seen more frequently in older children and adults with CF, especially after the introduction of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT).

 

The treatment of choice for distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), which primarily involves the use of laxatives like PEG (Polyethylene glycol) is effective because it works by osmotically drawing water into the intestine, which helps to soften the stool and promote bowel movements, thereby alleviating the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein losing enteropathy: This condition can occur in CF, but it is more common in the infantile period or up to 2 years of age due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. It is not a primary concern in a 10-year-old child with CF presenting with the given symptoms.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia is not typically seen in CF. Instead, CF patients often exhibit hyponatremia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss through sweat. This electrolyte imbalance is characteristic of CF.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse occurs after treatment: Rectal prolapse was historically a common manifestation of untreated CF in young children. However, with effective treatment, including pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, rectal prolapse is now rare and does not usually occur after treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: What kind of symptoms does the term affective flattening imply? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative symptoms

 

Affective flattening is a negative symptom characterized by:

 

  • Lack of emotional response/emotional blunting
  • Decreased expression of emotions
    • It is one of the 6 A's of negative symptoms (others being Avolition, Apathy, Anhedonia, Asociality, and Alogia). 
    • Negative symptoms represent a reduction or loss of normal functions, unlike positive symptoms which represent an excess or distortion of normal functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive symptoms: Incorrect because positive symptoms represent excess or distortion of normal functions (like hallucinations and delusions). Affective flattening represents a reduction in emotional expression, making it a negative symptom.

 

Option C. Affect symptoms: Incorrect because while affective flattening involves affect, it's specifically categorized as a negative symptom due to its nature of representing a reduction in normal emotional expression.

 

Option D. Cognitive symptoms: Incorrect because cognitive symptoms relate to thinking and mental processes like attention, memory, and executive function. Affective flattening is related to emotional expression, not cognitive function.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 years

 

Brain growth reaches its maximum around 2 years of age. This early and rapid growth phase is crucial for the development of cognitive and motor skills, and it aligns with significant milestones in early childhood development, such as language acquisition, sensory processing, and coordination. The early years are critical for brain development, as synaptic connections are formed at a rapid pace during this time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 years: At 6 years of age, the lymphoid tissues reach their maximum size. The lymphoid system includes the tonsils, adenoids, and other components of the immune system, which are prominent in early childhood to protect against infections.

 

Option C. 10 years: This age is not specifically associated with peak growth in any of the major developmental domains mentioned (brain, lymphoid, somatic, or puberty).

 

Option D. 12 years: This age marks the peak growth for somatic (body) growth and the onset of puberty. During this period, there is a significant increase in height and secondary sexual characteristics as the body undergoes maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.

 

Remember:

 

  • Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: A carpenter complains of swelling around knee as shown in the given image. What is most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Housemaid knee

 

The condition shown in the image is most consistent with prepatellar bursitis, commonly known as "Housemaid's knee." The bursa acts as a cushion between the patella and skin to reduce friction during movement. prepatellar bursitis is characterized by inflammation of the prepatellar bursa, located just in front of the patella (kneecap). It is often associated with occupations or activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as carpentry.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clergyman knee: Incorrect. Also known as infrapatellar bursitis, where the inflammation occurs below the patella due to prolonged kneeling. However, the swelling is typically observed in the infrapatellar region, not over the prepatellar area as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Abscess: Incorrect. While an abscess can cause localized swelling, it is often accompanied by additional signs of infection such as redness, warmth, pain, and systemic symptoms like fever

 

Option D. Oedema: Incorrect. Oedema is generalized swelling due to fluid accumulation, not be localized to just the prepatellar area it typically affects both legs and show pitting on pressure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prepatellar bursitis, or "Housemaid's knee," results from repetitive trauma or prolonged kneeling. It presents as localized swelling over the prepatellar area and is a common occupational hazard for individuals who frequently kneel, such as carpenters.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability, which typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The hallmark of MG is weakness that is more pronounced towards the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and this weakness improves after a period of rest.

 

Key features in this patient’s presentation include:

 

  • Generalized weakness that increases in the evening.
  • Improvement in weakness with short rest periods.
  • Presence of ptosis (drooping eyelids) and difficulty in swallowing, which are common manifestations of MG.

 

In MG, autoantibodies attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with small cell lung cancer. It also involves muscle weakness but typically improves with exercise rather than worsening, which is opposite to the pattern seen in MG.

 

Option C. Peripheral Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy generally presents with sensory disturbances, weakness, and diminished reflexes in a stocking-glove distribution. It does not typically cause fluctuating weakness or specific muscle group involvement such as ptosis.

 

Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder that presents in early childhood with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. It is highly unlikely to present in a 76-year-old man as it typically leads to severe disability or death by early adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.

 

Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elastic cartilage

 

The image shows elastic cartilage, characterized by:

 

  • More loosely arranged chondrocytes
  • Matrix containing fine elastic fibers (appearing as thin branching lines)
  • Less ground substance compared to hyaline cartilage
  • Multiple nuclei visible in each lacuna
  • The elastic fibers provide flexibility while maintaining shape
  • Found in structures like ear pinna, epiglottis, and parts of the larynx

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyaline cartilage: Incorrect because hyaline cartilage has a more homogeneous glassy matrix without visible fibers and more regularly arranged chondrocytes.

 

Option C. Fibrocartilage: Incorrect because fibrocartilage shows dense parallel bundles of collagen fibers with chondrocytes arranged in rows between them, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Articular cartilage: Incorrect because articular cartilage is a type of hyaline cartilage found at joint surfaces. The histological features shown here are characteristic of elastic cartilage, not articular cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elastic cartilage is identified by the presence of elastic fibers within its matrix, which provides flexibility and strength. It is found in the pinna of the ear, epiglottis, and Eustachian tube.

questions.text: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition. [NEET PG  2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine

 

Given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of neurolathyrism, for which the toxin responsible is beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA).

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings
  • Osteolathyrism: In animals

 

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Lathyrism affects 15 - 45 years of age

 

  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)’Q
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of Lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: Steeping method and Parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aflatoxin: Toxin produced by Aspergillus species. It causes aflatoxicosis and is commonly found in contaminated ground nuts.

 

Option C. Ergot alkaloids: Toxins produced by Claviceps species, leading to ergotism. Found in contaminated cereals.

 

Option D. Fusarium toxin: Toxins produced by Fusarium species, which can contaminate grains and other food products, causing fusarium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which causes an obstruction to blood flow. This condition leads to high blood pressure in the arteries that are proximal to the narrowing (upper limbs) and lower blood pressure in the arteries distal to the narrowing (lower limbs).

 

The key findings in this scenario include:

 

  • Feeble femoral pulses: Due to reduced blood flow past the coarctation.
  • Upper limb hypertension: Caused by increased resistance proximal to the coarctation.
  • Chest X-ray showing enlarged intercostal arteries: These develop as collateral circulation to bypass the coarctation, which can cause rib notching seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the septum between the heart's atria. It typically causes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow and right heart overload. It does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option C. Bicuspid aortic valve: A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital valve anomaly that can lead to aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause differential blood pressure between the limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA is a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. It causes a continuous murmur and can lead to heart failure if significant but does not cause differential blood pressure or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in patients with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, feeble femoral pulses, and chest X-ray findings of enlarged intercostal arteries, indicating collateral circulation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. She is a known case of rheumatic heart disease. On examination, the apical impulse is hyperdynamic, and a "pistol shot" sound is heard over the femoral artery. The pulse is collapsing and water hammer-like. Auscultation reveals a pansystolic murmur and an early diastolic murmur. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation + Mitral regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features suggest a combined valvular lesion with predominant aortic regurgitation (AR) and mitral regurgitation (MR):

 

  • Pistol shot sounds (also called Traube’s sign or pistol shot femorals)
  • Collapsing/water hammer pulse (Watson’s water hammer pulse)
  • Early diastolic murmur – Characteristic of AR
  • Pansystolic murmur – Characteristic of MR
  • Hyperdynamic apex – Seen in volume overload conditions like AR and MR
  • History of rheumatic heart disease, which commonly affects the mitral and aortic valves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis + Mitral regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • MS produces a mid-diastolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • MS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • MS typically causes a tapping apex, not hyperdynamic

 

Option C. Mitral stenosis + Aortic regurgitation: Incorrect because:

 

  • No mid-diastolic murmur of MS described
  • Pansystolic murmur indicates MR, not MS

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation + Aortic stenosis: Incorrect because:

 

  • AS produces an ejection systolic murmur, not early diastolic
  • AS does not cause collapsing pulse or pistol shot sounds
  • AS typically causes a sustained apex beat, not hyperdynamic

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of combined aortic regurgitation and mitral regurgitation include:

 

  • Early diastolic murmur (AR)
  • Pansystolic murmur (MR)
  • Pistol shot sounds and water hammer pulse (AR)
  • Hyperdynamic apex (volume overload)

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the MRCP image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Choledochal cyst

 

The MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) image shows a fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct (CBD), which is characteristic of a choledochal cyst, specifically Type 1. Type 1 choledochal cysts are the most common type and are characterized by this distinctive fusiform dilatation of the CBD. Choledochal cysts are congenital anomalies of the bile duct that can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, jaundice, or pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cholangiocarcinoma: This is a malignant tumor of the bile ducts that typically appears as a mass, often associated with bile duct obstruction. The classic presentation on imaging is a mass lesion, often seen at the perihilar (Klatskin tumor) or distal bile ducts, which is not observed in the provided image.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This rare congenital disorder involves the dilation of intrahepatic bile ducts, not extrahepatic ones like the CBD. A key imaging feature of Caroli disease is the "central dot sign," where dilated bile ducts contain a small dot representing a portal vein radical, which is absent in this image.

 

Option D. Choledocholithiasis: This condition involves the presence of stones within the bile ducts, which appear as signal voids on MRCP. The provided image does not show such signal voids, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fusiform dilatation of the common bile duct on MRCP is characteristic of a Type 1 choledochal cyst, the most common type of choledochal cyst.

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presented with gum bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue. He was suffering from fever for 1 month and on examination, he had pallor and a petechial rash distributed all over the body. His peripheral smear revealed macrocytes and his corrected reticulocyte count was 0.5%. Bone marrow revealed few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells. What should be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Idiopathic Acquired Aplastic Anemia

 

The patient's presentation of gum bleeding, easy bruising, fatigue, fever, pallor, and petechial rash suggests Pancytopenia. Pancytopenia can result from several conditions, but the key clues here are:

 

  • Bone marrow findings: The bone marrow shows few fatty streaks, no immature cells, and no inflammatory cells, indicating a hypocellular marrow.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count: A low corrected reticulocyte count (0.5%) indicates poor bone marrow response.

 

These findings are characteristic of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia, a condition where the bone marrow fails to produce adequate amounts of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disseminated TB: Disseminated TB usually presents with systemic symptoms and may show a cellular bone marrow due to granulomas and other inflammatory changes, which is not consistent with the findings of a hypocellular marrow.

 

Option C. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH typically presents with hemolytic anemia, thrombosis, and sometimes pancytopenia. However, it usually shows a cellular marrow unless it is associated with aplastic anemia. In exams, PNH is generally considered a cause of cellular marrow.

 

Option D. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS usually presents with a hypercellular or normocellular marrow with dysplastic changes. It can cause pancytopenia, but the marrow is typically not hypocellular except in rare cases of hypoplastic MDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia should be considered in patients presenting with pancytopenia, bleeding, bruising, fatigue, and hypocellular bone marrow without significant inflammatory or immature cells. The diagnosis is supported by a low corrected reticulocyte count and clinical findings consistent with bone marrow failure.

questions.text: A 6-week-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent projectile vomiting. USG of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 

The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is commonly seen in infants, particularly around 6 weeks of age, and is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting due to the thickening of the pyloric muscle, which leads to gastric outlet obstruction. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis, showing a thickened hypoechoic pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal, confirming the presence of CHPS. Key diagnostic measurements on ultrasound include pyloric muscle thickness greater than 4 mm and canal length greater than 16 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Typically presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with the “double bubble” sign on X-ray, not ultrasound. It does not present with projectile vomiting.

 

Option B. Jejunal atresia: Presents with bilious vomiting and is associated with a “triple bubble” sign on imaging studies, typically on X-ray. This condition does not match the clinical presentation or the ultrasound findings shown in the question.

 

Option D. Midgut volvulus: This condition presents with bilious vomiting and can show a corkscrew sign on contrast imaging studies due to the twisting of the bowel on its own axis. It is diagnosed using contrast imaging, not ultrasound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CHPS is characterized by projectile, non-bilious vomiting in an infant around 6 weeks of age, and is best diagnosed with an ultrasound showing thickened pyloric muscle and a narrowed pyloric canal.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Histidine

 

Histidine contains an imidazole ring in its side chain, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~6.8-7.0).

 

The imidazole ring allows histidine to reversibly bind and release protons, making it an excellent buffer.

 

This buffering action is important in maintaining blood pH and plays a key role in hemoglobin function (part of the histidine residue in hemoglobin helps buffer blood pH changes).

 

"Histidine has an imidazole ring, which allows it to accept and donate protons at physiological pH."

 

"Histidine is the most effective buffer at physiological pH due to its imidazole ring."

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Arginine: Incorrect

 

  • Has a guanidinium group with pKa ~12.5, making it a strong base, but not an effective buffer at physiological pH (~7.4).
  • Arginine is the precursor of nitric oxide (NO), emphasizing its role in vasodilation rather than acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Tryptophan: Incorrect

 

  • Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid and is used in the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3), serotonin, and melatonin.
  • Tryptophan contains an indole ring, making it non-polar and hydrophobic.
  • Since buffering depends on the ability to accept and donate protons near physiological pH (~7.4), tryptophan is not effective as a buffer.

 

Option D. Tyrosine: Incorrect

 

  • Tyrosine's is derived from phenylalanine and has a role in thyroid hormone synthesis, catecholamine production (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine), and melanin production.
  • Tyrosine has a phenol (-OH) group, with a pKa of ~10.1, meaning it does not donate or accept protons effectively at physiological pH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histidine is the best amino acid buffer in blood because of its imidazole ring, which has a pKa close to physiological pH (~7).

 

The imidazole group allows histidine to act as a proton donor or acceptor, making it an ideal buffer.

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim was examined in court "in camera." What does it imply? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

 

"In camera" is a legal term used to describe a judicial proceeding that is held privately, away from the public and the media.
