This setting is particularly used in sensitive cases, such as those involving sexual assault, to protect the privacy and dignity of the victim. In such proceedings, only selected individuals, such as the judge, lawyers, the accused, the victim, and sometimes a few relatives of the victim, are allowed to be present.

 

This type of trial is mandated in India for all sexual assault cases to ensure the victim's confidentiality and provide a safe environment free from public scrutiny. It is not a public trial, and the general public is not allowed to attend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open proceeding: An open proceeding is accessible to the public and media, which is not suitable for sensitive cases like sexual assault due to privacy concerns. This option is incorrect because "in camera" specifically denotes a closed proceeding.

 

Option C. Recorded in camera: This option might seem correct due to the term "camera," but it does not mean the proceedings are being recorded. "In camera" refers to the closed nature of the trial, not to any form of recording.

 

Option D. Proceedings in another place: This option incorrectly implies that the trial is conducted at a different location. However, "in camera" refers to the nature of the trial being private, not about the location of the proceedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text: Elderly male with a 3-week presents with history of trauma, with CT brain image as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SDH (Subdural Hematoma)

 

The correct diagnosis is Subdural Hematoma (SDH). In elderly patients with a history of trauma, a sub-acute subdural hematoma often presents with symptoms that develop gradually over weeks due to slow venous bleeding. The CT scan shows a crescent-shaped (banana-shaped) hyperdense area, which is characteristic of a subdural hematoma. The chronic nature of the subdural hematoma is suggested by the time course (3 weeks’ post-trauma) and is more common in the elderly due to brain atrophy, which increases the risk of bridging vein tears leading to SDH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EDH (Epidural Hematoma): An epidural hematoma typically presents with a biconvex (lens-shaped) appearance on CT imaging, occurring between the skull and the dura mater. It is often associated with a more acute presentation following head trauma, usually involving arterial bleeding, and is less common in the elderly unless there is a direct skull fracture involving the middle meningeal artery.

 

Option C. SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage): A subarachnoid hemorrhage presents as hyperdensity in the basal cisterns, sulci, or along the surface of the brain on CT. It is most commonly associated with ruptured aneurysms and would not present with a crescent or banana-shaped lesion as seen in the provided CT image.

 

Option D. Contusion: A contusion would show localized areas of bleeding or edema within the brain tissue itself, often with a mixed density appearance due to the presence of both hemorrhage and edema. Contusions do not have the crescent shape seen with SDH.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic Subdural Hematoma (SDH) is often seen in elderly patients with a history of minor trauma, presenting weeks after the injury with symptoms such as headache, confusion, or neurological deficits. The characteristic CT finding is a crescent-shaped collection along the convexity of the brain, distinguishing it from other types of intracranial hemorrhages.

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with hearing difficulty. On examination, the Rinne test is positive in the right ear and negative in the left ear. Weber's test shows lateralization to the right. Bone conduction is reduced in the left ear and normal in the right ear. What is the most likely interpretation of these findings? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

 

Explanation: 


The findings indicate severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear because:

 

  • Left ear shows Rinne negative test (false negative)
  • Weber lateralizes to right (better hearing) ear
  • Reduced bone conduction in left ear confirms inner ear pathology
  • This pattern occurs in severe unilateral SNHL where: 
    • Sound during bone conduction testing crosses to the normal ear (cross hearing)
    • Creates false impression of bone conduction better than air conduction
    • True pathology revealed by Weber test lateralizing away from affected ear
    • Reduced bone conduction confirms SNHL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conductive hearing loss in the left ear

 

  • Would show true Rinne negative
  • Weber would lateralize to affected (left) ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be positive in right ear (correct)
  • Weber would lateralize to left (unaffected) ear
  • Bone conduction would be reduced in right ear

 

Option C. Conductive hearing loss in the right ear

 

  • Rinne would be negative in right ear
  • Weber would lateralize to right ear
  • Bone conduction would be normal

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative Rinne test with reduced bone conduction and Weber’s test lateralizing to the opposite ear suggests sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) in the affected ear.

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement in a 3-days old baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 120-130 ml/kg/day

 

The fluid requirement for a 3-days old baby weighing less than 1500 grams, such as a baby with a birth weight of 1300 grams, is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This is based on NICU protocols that specify fluid needs according to the day of life and the birth weight of the neonate. At day 3 of life, the recommended fluid intake increases from the previous days to ensure adequate hydration and metabolic support for preterm neonates.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 80-90 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is appropriate for the first day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option B. 100-110 ml/kg/day: This range is suitable for the second day of life for preterm neonates with a birth weight of less than 1500 grams, not for the third day.

 

Option D. 130-150 ml/kg/day: This fluid requirement is higher than the recommended range for a 3-day-old baby weighing 1300 grams. This range is appropriate for the fourth day of life or beyond for preterm neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-day-old preterm baby weighing less than 1500 grams, the fluid requirement is 120-130 ml/kg/day. This ensures proper hydration and metabolic support during this critical period.

questions.text: Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gestational thrombocytopenia

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy. It is generally a benign condition associated with mild thrombocytopenia, where platelet counts typically range between 100,000 to 150,000 per microliter. It is not linked to adverse pregnancy outcomes and usually resolves spontaneously after delivery. The exact cause is not well understood, but it is believed to be related to the normal hemodilution and increased platelet turnover during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ITP (Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): While ITP can cause thrombocytopenia in pregnancy, it is less common than gestational thrombocytopenia. ITP involves an autoimmune response leading to severe platelet destruction.

 

Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia that includes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. While it causes thrombocytopenia, it is not as common as gestational thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Malaria in pregnancy: Malaria can cause thrombocytopenia, but it is not the most common cause during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of mild thrombocytopenia during pregnancy and is usually not associated with adverse outcomes.

questions.text: Enzyme defect in McArdle’s Disease?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myophosphorylase

 

This is the correct answer. McArdle's Disease results from a deficiency of myophosphorylase, which is an enzyme responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within muscle cells. The lack of myophosphorylase impairs the ability of muscle cells to release glucose from glycogen during physical activity, leading to muscle fatigue, pain, and other symptoms typically observed in McArdle's Disease patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucose-6-phosphatase: This enzyme is involved in glucose metabolism in the liver, not in muscle cells. Deficiencies in glucose-6-phosphatase lead to other types of Glycogen Storage Diseases, such as Von Gierke's Disease (GSD Ia).

 

Option C. Glycogen synthase : While this enzyme plays a role in glycogen metabolism, it is not the enzyme affected in McArdle's Disease. Instead, it is myophosphorylase that is deficient in this condition.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is involved in the initial steps of glucose metabolism but is not directly related to glycogen breakdown or McArdle's Disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McArdle's disease is Type V glycogen storage disease that occurs due to deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase (Myophosphorylase) enzyme. In this disease, muscle glycogen cannot be used during exercise, so, on strenuous exercise there are muscles cramps. Also, normal or relatively low levels of lactate will be formed from muscle glycogen after exercise.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 167
